metadata.case_name: Nar Singh and Roshan Singh v. State

facts.text: Twenty-four persons, among them the two appellants Nar Singh and Roshan Singh, were tried for offences under sections 148, 307/149 and 302/149, Indian Penal Code.
Sixteen were acquitted and the remaining eight were convicted.
On appeal to the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad, five more were acquitted and the convictions were upheld only for the two appellants Nar Singh and Roshan Singh, and one Nanhu Singh.
High Court misread evidence and mixed up Nanhu Singh with Bechan Singh; meant to convict Bechan and acquit Nanhu, but acquitted Bechan and convicted Nanhu.
High Court Judges realised mistake, communicated with State Government; Government remitted sentence on Nanhu Singh and directed his release.
Application under Article 134(1)(c) by Nanhu Singh, Nar Singh and Roshan Singh for certificate; granted to all.
High Court considered certificate proper for Nanhu due to stigma of conviction despite remission; for appellants, no exceptional nature but granted as part of whole appeal.
Nanhu did not appeal to Supreme Court; only Nar Singh and Roshan Singh appealed.
A number of persons joined in an attack at two in the morning on helpless persons who were asleep in bed.
High Court finding: more than five persons involved; eye-witnesses identify the two appellants.
Only two out of the band of attackers were satisfactorily identified.

legal_issues.text: Whether the certificate under Article 134(1)(c) was properly granted to Nar Singh and Roshan Singh.
Meaning of 'case' in Article 134(1)(c): whether it refers to the appeal as a whole or each individual's case.
Scope of Supreme Court's jurisdiction upon grant of certificate under Article 134(1)(c): whether it becomes ordinary appellate court on facts and law.
Justification for use of Section 149 IPC given more than five persons involved.

petitioner_arguments.text: Having obtained a certificate under Article 134(1)(c), Supreme Court becomes an ordinary Court of appeal and is bound to hear their case as an appellate Court both on facts and on law.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Subhanand Chowdhary v. Apurba Krishna Mitra; Article 134(1)(c)

court_reasoning.text: 'Case' in Article 134(1)(c) means the case of each individual person, not the appeal as a whole; even if joint memorandum, each appeal is separate.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court wrongly thought bound to grant certificate to all as one case.

court_reasoning.text: Certificate under Article 134(1)(c) involves judicial discretion exercised on well-established lines; Supreme Court can review if misdirected.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court misdirected itself, fettered discretion wrongly.

court_reasoning.text: Subhanand Chowdhary inapplicable as deals with different provision (Section 205, 1935 Act).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Supreme Court retains power to determine if certificate rightly granted.

court_reasoning.text: Treating as Article 136 petition: no special grounds; evidence clear, High Court believed eye-witnesses identifying appellants; more than five involved justifies Section 149 IPC.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mere identification of two does not weaken finding of more than five.

holdings.text: Certificate under Article 134(1)(c) wrongly granted to appellants; treat appeal as petition under Article 136 for special leave, which is rejected.
'Case' means individual case, not entire appeal.
Convictions under Sections 148, 307/149, 302/149 IPC proper; no interference with sentences.

precedents_cited.case_name: Subhanand Chowdhary v. Apurba Krishna Mitra
precedents_cited.relevance: Deals with Section 205 of 1935 Act, different from Article 134(1)(c)
Certificate must show discretion invoked and exercised

precedents_cited.relevance: Certificate must show discretion invoked and exercised

No interference with discretion unless strong grounds

precedents_cited.relevance: Superior court must remit or exercise discretion if misdirection

statutes_cited.relevance: Offences for which appellants convicted; Section 149 justified as more than five involved

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal to Supreme Court; discretion judicially exercised; fallback to special leave

outcome.summary: Supreme Court held certificate wrongly granted, treated appeal as Article 136 special leave petition and dismissed it; upheld convictions and sentences of Nar Singh and Roshan Singh under Sections 148, 307/149, 302/149 IPC.

key_quotes.text: 'Case' as used there means the case of each individual person.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core interpretation rejecting High Court's view of joint appeal as single case

key_quotes.text: Ordinarily no certificate can be granted to them as there is nothing of an exceptional nature in their cases.
key_quotes.speaker: lower_court
key_quotes.significance: High Court's own admission no merit in appellants' cases

key_quotes.text: The mere fact that only two out of the band of attackers were satisfactorily identified does not weaken the force of the finding that more than five were involved.
key_quotes.speaker: court
